comments.body: is -v necessary? Might make logs harder to parse.
It's how we do almost all our tests...  we could miss some output on a failure if we don't do a -v (e.g. stacktraces aren't printed)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +10,14 @@pushd .ios
xcodebuild -workspace Runner.xcworkspace -scheme Runner -destination generic/platform=iOS -configuration Debug CODE_SIGNING_REQUIRED=NO CODE_SIGNING_IDENTITY="" CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=NO
xcodebuild -workspace Runner.xcworkspace -scheme Runner -destination generic/platform=iOS -configuration Profile CODE_SIGNING_REQUIRED=NO CODE_SIGNING_IDENTITY="" CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=NO
xcodebuild -workspace Runner.xcworkspace -scheme Runner -destination generic/platform=iOS -configuration Release CODE_SIGNING_REQUIRED=NO CODE_SIGNING_IDENTITY="" CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=NO
popd

comments.body: You're testing on a simulator below anyway. Build x86 to make things marginally faster.
What is the xcpretty stuff for? Make it more legible how?

it turns the wall of xcodebuild output into an easier to read format - e.g. the test output now looks like: 
```
~/src/flutter/dev/integration_tests/ios_add2app/flutterapp ~/src/flutter/dev/integration_tests/ios_add2app
```

Interesting.  Looks like there's also https://github.com/thii/xcbeautify which might be more up to date.
I have no strong preferences there - we're using xcpretty in a few other places already though
